Monroe County School Superintendents Outstanding Senior Recognition Program on WHAM

Wheatland-Chili Senior Sarah Allen was selected for this honor due to the leadership and service that she has demonstrated within and outside of the school community, as well as her focus on academics.

Sarah was a member of the Jazz Band, Pit Band, Drama Club, International Club, Leadership Asset Training, and the National Honor Society. She played Varsity Soccer, Softball, Swimming, and Tennis. As a junior, Sarah received the Frederick Douglass/Susan B Anthony Award. We wish her all the best as she heads to the University of Oregon to study Marine Biology.

Each year, one student from every high school in Monroe County is selected, by their Superintendent, as the outstanding senior based on scholarship, leadership, service, and character.

Fireworks Display to Celebrate the Class of 2020

The District is hosting a fireworks display to celebrate the Class of 2020. The display is open to the Wheatland-Chili School Community. Please plan to join us on Friday, June 26, at the Middle School/High School. The fireworks display will begin at dark (approximately 9:30 p.m.). We changed our Fireworks display to Friday, June 26, due to the Saturday forecast of rain. The Rain Date will be Sunday, June 28.

The fireworks display will be held on District property with a drive-in style viewing. We ask that you stay in your vehicle to view the fireworks. Individuals who are not in vehicles must observe CDC guidelines of social distancing and/or the wearing of masks when social distancing is not possible.

The campus will be open at 8:45 p.m. for cars to begin parking in the lot in the front of the school and behind the school to view the fireworks display launched from the old softball field. The buildings are closed and no restroom facilities are available.

2nd place out of 5 at the Genesee Region League Championship!!! With a team of only 5 they killed it! They also Hit 0 (zero deductions) with a flawless routine 😍

For those that don't know, having a team of less than 8 makes it very difficult to score well because certain things are required of teams. Such as having a minimum of 2 stunts. While it is technically possible to do with 6 or 7, it is impossible with 5. So we enter every competition at an automatic disadvantage. For this small team of 5 to be able to grab second place against teams larger than ourselves is a monumental feat. These are very hardworking and determined kids. They know that the odds are against them everytime, but they still go out there and perform because they love this sport. As a coach, I know I've done my job when my athletes love the sport as much as me. The wins aren't as important as the passion.

Now we will spend the next week preparing for Sectionals on Saturday! Watch out, because these Wildcats are comin' for ya 🐾

After 29 years with the Wheatland-Chili School District, Mary Pat Tobey is retiring today. Tobey worked in the District Business Office as Payroll Clerk for almost three decades. In this position she managed payroll, employee benefits, retirement, health insurance, and compiled quarterly and yearly reports. She also served as the United Way Campaign Coordinator for more than 20 years.
“I will miss the day-to-day interactions with employees,” said Tobey. “I am lucky to have so many wonderful coworkers.”
In retirement, Tobey is looking forward to traveling and spending time with her children and grandchildren. She has already planned trips to Colorado and Florida.
“I am very grateful for the thirty years I spent at Wheatland-Chili,” said Tobey. “I look forward to everything retirement holds for me.”

On Monday, November 18, fifteen juniors and seniors attended the Historically Black Colleges and Universities Event at the Rochester Riverside Convention Center. During the event, students engaged in college readiness workshops, connected with college reps and other organizations in the college tour zone, and also learned about in-demand careers from professionals in the career zone area. One senior met with college admissions reps and secured scholarship monies if she chooses to attend one of those schools.

A panel discussion held regarding financial aid provided students with great information about the importance of completing the FAFSA (if the student is currently a senior and applying to colleges this year). After lunch, another panel discussion addressed positive relationships - personally and professionally. Over 1400 students from Rochester, Buffalo, and Syracuse high schools attended. Students are already
planning next year's trip.

According to one junior the day was "very informative" and she is glad she went.

In November of 2019, Marie McCarthy will celebrate 20 years as a bus driver with Wheatland-Chili Central School District. McCarthy was honored at the beginning of the school year for her years of service. Her favorite part of her job is being around the students. “They’re funny,” she said.

“I make sure that the kids get safely from point A to point B, ” said McCarthy. “That’s by far the most important part of my job.”

Originally from Attica, McCarthy attended school in Alexander. Prior to coming to Wheatland-Chili, she drove for Laidlaw out of Batavia and was a substitute bus driver for Pembroke. McCarthy has three children and two grandchildren. Her oldest child lives in Hawai’i where she visits him every other year. Outside of work, she enjoys antiquing, gardening, and reading. “I read every day. Every single day, without fail.”

Wheatland-Chili Girls Soccer
October 4, 2019 at 1:24 AM ·

The Wildcats are back home following a week-long & rain-soaked road trip. On Tuesday they won in a weather-shortened game at Attica 5-0. Lindsey Clar and Niyah Rosado each had a brace (2G) and 8th-grade defender Hannalee Hotaling netted her first career varsity goal for the Wildcats!
Tonight they traveled north to Lyndonville and returned with a 7-0 win. The defense now has a total of 9 shutouts on the season. Scoring for the Wildcats were Emily Parker, Scout Brandes, Jenna LaMere and Niyah Rosado finished with 4 goals, the last of which was her 100th career goal! She becomes only the second WCGVS player to reach triple digits. Congratulations Niyah!
